xxl.core.pipes.processors
Class Processor

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Thread
      xxl.core.pipes.processors.Processor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Runnable, MetaDataManageable<Object,Object>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>
Direct Known Subclasses:
MetaDataLogger.MetaDataAccessor, QueryExecutor, SchedulableProcessor, SWTPerformanceMonitor.MetaDataAccessor, UrgentProcessor
public abstract class Processor
extends Thread
implements MetaDataManageable<Object,Object>

Extension of the class Thread, which is used to simulate activity in a query graph.
The run method of this class looks as follows: 

        time = System.currentTimeMillis();
        while (!terminate) {
                if (period > 0)
                        delay();
                process();
        }
A thread, in this framework named processor, executes its abstract process method until the flag terminate is set. Usually this happens through another thread. An additional delay may be inserted, if the parameter period has been specified. The method delay invokes a (non-blocking) wait call on an instance of a class inheriting from this abstract one. Thereby this instance relinquishes any and all synchronization claims for the specified amount of time, so that other threads may be executed. No class should inherit directly from Processor but from SchedulableProcessor or UrgentProcessor.

Since:
1.1
See Also:
SchedulableProcessor, UrgentProcessor, Thread

Field Detail

scheduler

protected static Scheduler scheduler
The Scheduler used by all Processors.

delayManager

protected Cursor<Long> delayManager
The delaymanager always determines the delay between two successive process calls (in milliseconds). The return type is always a Long.

delay

protected long delay
Delay between two successive process calls (in milliseconds).

time

protected long time
Point in time, when the last process call was executed.

latency

protected long latency
Remaining delay. The time needed to perform the process method is subtracted.

additionalLatency

protected long additionalLatency
Remaining latency, if the parameter period has been chosen smaller than 15.625 ms on Windows plattforms or 19.99 ms on Linux plattforms, because the timer-interrupt of these plattforms are only updated in these timer intervals. Therefore some wait calls delay the process execution more than period milliseconds. In order to offer a nearly exact timing this parameter stores the additional latency and and the wait method is only invoked, if this parameter is smaller than the specified parameter period.

terminate

protected volatile boolean terminate
Flag used to terminate this thread's execution.

first

protected boolean first
Flag that signals, if it is the first call to the delay method.

waitForWakeUp

protected boolean waitForWakeUp
Flag that signals, if the method pauseUntilWakeUp has been invoked and this instance still waits for a wake-up call.

schedulingPriority

protected int schedulingPriority
The scheduling priority for this Processor>/code>.

timer

protected Timer timer

zeroTime

protected long zeroTime

sleep

protected boolean sleep

metaDataManagement

protected Processor.ProcessorMetaDataManagement metaDataManagement

getSchedulingPriority

public int getSchedulingPriority()
Returns the scheduling priority of this Processor.

Returns:
The scheduling priority of this Processor.

setSchedulingPriority

public void setSchedulingPriority(int newSchedulingPriority)
Sets the scheduling priority of this Processor.

Parameters:
newSchedulingPriority - The new scheduling priority for this processor.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - If the specified priority is not in the range given by getMinSchedulingPriority() and getMaxSchedulingPriority() from the currently used scheduler. If no scheduler is used, all values are accepted.

delay

public void delay()
Synthetic delay inserted between two successive process calls. The length of this delay is given by the user via the parameter period. The time pertaining to the costs of the process method's execution are subtracted.
The method pauseExact is used to realize a nearly exact timing even for small delays.

process

public abstract void process()
Abstract method doing some user-defined operation periodically until this thread is terminated.

pause

public void pause(long millis)
Causes the current thread to wait for the specified time (milliseconds). Calls this.wait(millis).

Parameters:
millis - The time to wait (in ms).

pauseUntilWakeUp

public void pauseUntilWakeUp()
Causes the current thread to wait until an explicit call to wakeUp is applied to it.
Sets the flag waitForWakeUp.

pauseExact

public void pauseExact(long millis)
Causes the current thread to wait for the specified time (milliseconds), even if the parameter millis has been chosen smaller than 15.625 ms on Windows plattforms or 19.99 ms on Linux plattforms, because the timer-interrupt of these plattforms are only updated in these timer intervals. Therefore some usual wait calls delay more than millis milliseconds. In order to offer a nearly exact timing the parameter additionalLatency stores the additional latency and the wait method is only invoked, if this parameter is smaller than the specified parameter millis.

Parameters:
millis - The time to wait (in ms).

wakeUp

public void wakeUp()
Wakes up a single thread that is waiting on this object's monitor by calling this.notify().

setDelayManager

public void setDelayManager(Iterator<Long> delayManager)
Sets the DelayManager, which produce the delays between two successive process calls.

Parameters:
delayManager - The DelayManager, which produce delay between two successive process calls (in milliseconds).

getDelayManager

public Cursor<Long> getDelayManager()
Returns the DelayManager, which produce the delay between two successive process calls (in milliseconds).
Because the attribute delayManager is not denoted as volatile (modifier), read access has also to be synchronized with the aim to avoid missed updates of several threads monitoring this attribute.

Returns:
The delay between two successive process calls (in milliseconds).

getLastDelay

public long getLastDelay()
Returns the delay between the two last process calls (in milliseconds).

Returns:
The delay between the two last successive process calls (in milliseconds).

terminate

public void terminate()
Terminates this thread, i.e., this method sets the attribute terminate, which causes that the execution of this thread's run method is completed, whereupon the JVM stops and kills it.

isTerminated

public boolean isTerminated()

waitsForWakeUp

public boolean waitsForWakeUp()
Returns true, if this thread waits for a wake-up call, otherwise false.

Returns:
Returns true, if this thread waits for a wake-up call, otherwise false.

onStart

protected void onStart()
This method has to be called when a processor starts. The call should be the first statement in the run() method. This method should be used to inform a scheduler.

onBlocked

protected void onBlocked()
This method has to be called if this processor blocks for a unknown time. This method should be used to inform a scheduler.

onBlocked

protected void onBlocked(long millis)
This method has to be called if this processor blocks for millis ms. This method should be used to inform a scheduler.

onUnblocked

protected void onUnblocked()
This method has to be called if this processor unblocks. This method should be used to inform a scheduler.

onTermination

protected void onTermination()
This method has to be called when a processor treminates. The call should be the last statement in the run() method. This method should be used to inform a scheduler.

onPriorityChange

protected void onPriorityChange()
This method has to be called if the scheduling priority of this processor changes. This method should be used to inform a scheduler.

initializeTimer

protected void initializeTimer()
